content: • Propose one-off bond issuance from EU Commission to finance the fund, with money to be spent through a combination of both grants (through EU budget) and loans with a very long maturity
analysis_details:
• Such a proposal, particularly in terms of the financing, could be taken as a potential way to resolve some of the disagreements between those nations favouring loans and those who would prefer additional funding to be distributed by grants
  • Earlier this morning, Eurogroup head Centeno says there are discussions for an ESM credit line with maturity of up to 10yrs. 
  • Comes ahead of today's Eurogroup Meeting - exact timing/schedule for this currently unclear

subject: Wirecard (WDI GY) - Bafin states that they are investigating the Co's communication directly prior to the publication of the KPMG audit
reaction_details: • In a marginally delayed reaction Co. shares came under pressure dropping from EUR 88.50 to EUR 87.00
analysis_details: • KPMG special reported has not identified incriminating evidence for public allegation of balance sheet forgery. With respect to all four areas of audit, no significant findings have been made. The audit report has not revealed any deviation between reported revenue and account balanced. Not all data could be obtained that would have been required to proof revenue in these years as required data are primarily controlled by third parties. KPMG has identified documentation and organisational weakness during audit period – which Wirecard has already identified and remedied these weaknesses since 2019. Release of annual accounts and press conference will not take place on 30th April. Wirecard will coordinate as soon as possible with EY when audit measures can be completed, taking into account COVID-19 restrictions and completion of KPMG report.

subject: SUMMARY: Negative rates – recent remarks from Fed officials, Trump Administration, others
content:
2020 VOTERS:

  • Fed chair Powell: 15/Mar/20: Fed does not see negative interest rates as appropriate policy response in the US. 11/Feb/20: Asked about negative interest rates, Powell says would prefer to rely on tools we did use rather than negative rates. 13/Nov/19: Negative interest rates would "certainly not be" appropriate in the current environment. 08/Oct/19: Did not see negative rates as appropriate tool. 18/Sep/19: If Fed was at zero lower bound again, does not think would use negative interest rates.
  • Fed VC Clarida: 18/Oct/19: Negative rates and currency changes are impacting capital flows in ways they weren’t before. 04/Oct/19 negative rates abroad sent capital to the US and flattened the yield curve.
  • Williams: 02/Oct/19: If Europe is successful using negative rates to create more growth, that will benefit the US.
  • Brainard: 26/Nov/19: Possible benefits of negative interest rates are not worth the potential costs. 16/Oct/19: 'Strong preference' is to address effective lower bound with existing tools, negative rates 'unattractive' for US.
  • Harker: 7/May/20: Negative interest rates have been tried in other places, nothing to make him think they are "worth a try" in US; negative interest rates would not have an effect on the economy during this crisis; evidence on effectiveness of negative interest rates globally is mixed; has a high hurdle for it. 17/Jan/20: Negative rates would be disruptive in the US. 12/Nov/19: In the case of recession the best response may not be negative rates but bigger fiscal stimulus.
  • Kaplan: 28/Feb/20: Does not want to see negative interest rates in US. 15/Jan/20: Central banks haven’t run out of ammunition and there is no evidence negative rates help economy. 17/Dec/19: Is determined not to use negative rates in the US. 03/Oct/19: negative rates in Europe show there are limits to monetary policy
  • Kashkari: 04/Nov/19: Fed does not think negative interest rates are a tool it would want to use, but does not rule out possibility. 11/Oct/19: asked about negative rates, Kashkari says ‘never say never’ but hopes to avoid them.
  • Mester: 03/Mar/20: sceptical that negative rates would work well in US. 14/Feb/20: says she is not a fan of negative interest rates for the US. 18/Nov/19: Would be very wary of using negative interest rates in the US as its financial system is different.

2020 NON-VOTERS:

  • Rosengren: 6/Mar/20: Sceptical about using negative interest rates in the US. 11/Nov/20: Doesn't think he personally would opt for negative rates in next recession. 20/Sep/19: Doesn’t think negative interest rates are ‘the way to go’ for monetary policy.
  • Bostic: 13/Jan/20: would prefer fed try other tools in a crisis before considering negative interest rates.
  • Bullard: 28/Feb/20: impact of negative rates so hard to see it is like the "smile on a dog".
  • Barkin: 3/Jan/20: Hasn’t seen anything in Europe or Japan that makes him interested in negative interest rates. 05/Nov/19: Not in favour of negative interest rates in the US.
  • Daly: 04/Nov/19: In her view, Fed is 'really far away' from going to negative rates.

FOMC MEETING MINUTES:

  • Mar 2020 meeting (8/Apr/20): A few participants were worried that policy actions would raise likelihood Market interest rates would fall below zero, counter to fed statements opposing negative rates
  • Oct 2019 meeting (20/Nov/19): In a review of strategy, all policymakers said  negative interest rates not an attractive tool; could reassess if warranted

US ADMINISTRATION OFFICIALS:

  • Trump: 18/Nov/19: He and Powell discussed interest rates, negative interest rates, low inflation, monetary policy easing, dollar strength, dollar impact on manufacturing, trade. 12/Nov/19: Regarding negative interest rates, Trump says 'give me some of that'. 30/Aug/19: Asked if he would like to see negative interest rates in the US, says no
  • Mnuchin: 19/Dec/19: Negative interest rates in Europe have led banks to hold dollars. 12/Sep/19: Negative interest rates in Europe are concerning, make it hard to have a good economy.
  • Hassett: 8/May/2020: IF the Fed pushed rates negative, he'd support itl he would not advise the Fed to do anything, they are independent.

OTHERS:

  • Gundlach 7/May/20: Pressure to go negative on Fed funds to build as short-term borrowing explodes; rates below zero would be fatal
  • Buffett 3/May/20: if interest rates go negative, investors ought to own equities, or at least 'something other than debt'
  • Dimon 22/Jan/20: Has some trepidation on negative rates
  • BIS 22/Sep/19: growing acceptance of negative interest rates "vaguely troubling"

subject: EU movers: ING Group (ING NA) +6%, Siemens (SIE GY) +4.2%, Ferrovial (FER SM) +3.2%, Airbus (AIR FP) +2.5%, Bechtle (BC8 GY) +2.5%, Leonardo (LDO IM) -1.9%

content:

Ahead, only Spanish ip before the US jobs data, but ECB President Lagarde is scheduled to orate again and may stress that fiscal policy is imperative to help combat the collateral damage from COVID-19, while reiterating that QE is backed by the ECJ and the Bank’s mandate. Back to Eurex, Bunds are still nudging higher and eyeing nearest resistance at 174.23 within a 173.80-174.18 range vs Thursday’s 173.89 close.

8 May 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real-time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board and US equity futures extended on gains overnight in which the Emini S&P and Mini Dow futures breached the 2900 and 24000 milestones respectively as global sentiment was underpinned amid renewed dialogue between US-China trade negotiators, whilst Fed Fund Rate futures began to price in negative rates for the US from December. ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.1%) were positive as they take impetus from their Wall St peers and with risk appetite spurred by loosening of coronavirus-related restrictions after Australia’s cabinet agreed to relax some of its social distancing measures in a 3-step phase and with Japan touting the early lifting of the state of emergency in some regions, while Japan is also said to mull additional measures including proposal to subsidize rents for small businesses for up to 6 months. subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 8th May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·        Asian equity markets were higher across the board and US equity futures extended on gains overnight

·        Chinese Vice Premier Liu He, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and USTR Lighthizer vowed to maintain efforts to implement the phase 1 deal

·        UK PM Johnson could ease aspects of the lockdown every two weeks, according to plans currently being discussed by ministers

·        The EU Commission is to make it less stringent for countries using ESM funds in which it will not require a macro-adjustment programme

·        Looking ahead, highlights include German Trade, US & Canadian Labour Market Reports, Baker Hughes Rig Count, Moody's on Italy & Greece. Note, UK markets are closed today

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US CDC reported total coronavirus cases as of previous day at 1600EDT increased to 1,219,066 (Prev. 1,193,813), while total death toll was at 73,297 (Prev. 70,802), while AFP tweeted there were 2,448 deaths in US over the last 24 hours, citing the Johns Hopkins tracker. (Newswires/Twitter)

US President Trump said he wants to ease travel restrictions at an appropriate time and that it is possible the administration will come up with further economic measures to help the people. In related news, it was also reported that the White House is considering actions it could take to stimulate the economy without requiring legislation and considering a possible delay in tax filing deadline, as well as moratorium on new regulations. (Newswires/NBC)

White House Trade Adviser Navarro said China vacuumed up all the world's personal protective equipment. In other news, US FDA reportedly withdrew approval for various companies making respirators in China and determined many N95 style masks made in China filtered out less than 95% of particular matter. (Newswires/SCMP)

Australian PM Morrison said today we will move ahead with reopening the economy and that the next step is to build confidence in the economy. PM Morrison added the cabinet agreed a 3-step plan to achieve COVID-safe economy by July and that the Treasury estimates 850k jobs will be restored under the plan in which retail, small cafes and restaurants will reopen, while it will allow the gathering of up to 10 people, with step 2 to allow gatherings up to 20 people and step 3 to allow gatherings of up to 100 people. (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose to 30,615 (Prev. 30,076) which is an increase of 539 vs. Prev. 649 increase. UK PM Johnson could ease aspects of the lockdown every two weeks, according to plans currently being discussed by ministers. (Telegraph) Other reports suggest that Britain will remain in lockdown until next month at the earliest. (Times)

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board and US equity futures extended on gains overnight in which the Emini S&P and Mini Dow futures breached the 2900 and 24000 milestones respectively as global sentiment was underpinned amid renewed dialogue between US-China trade negotiators, whilst Fed Fund Rate futures began to price in negative rates for the US from December. ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.1%) were positive as they take impetus from their Wall St peers and with risk appetite spurred by loosening of coronavirus-related restrictions after Australia’s cabinet agreed to relax some of its social distancing measures in a 3-step phase and with Japan touting the early lifting of the state of emergency in some regions, while Japan is also said to mull additional measures including proposal to subsidize rents for small businesses for up to 6 months. Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) joined in on the upbeat tone as Hong Kong reopens its bars and other venues from today, and due to the easing of trade tensions following a conference call between USTR Lighthizer, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and China Vice Premier Liu He in which the sides agreed to work together to create a beneficial environment for carrying out the trade deal and to strengthen cooperation on the macro economy. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially tracked upside in T-notes as US yields declined amid the pricing of future negative rates although the price action in JGBs was relatively tepid and the gains were later reversed following the 10yr inflation indexed bond auction which saw attracted weaker prices despite the amount sold just being half of the previous auction.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0788 vs. Exp. 7.0821 (Prev. 7.0931)

PBoC and China's SAFE finalized rules to cancel quotas under QFII and RQFII investor foreign investor schemes effective June 6th with the changes aimed at further opening up of China's financial markets. (Newswires)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and USTR Lighthizer spoke over the phone and agreed to keep communications, strengthen cooperation and vowed efforts to implement the phase 1 deal. The sides reportedly agreed to work together to create beneficial environment for carrying out trade deal, while they agreed good progress was made to make deal a success and that both sides fully expect obligations to be met. (Newswires/Xinhua)

UK/EU

EU Commission said ESM use will not require macro adjustment programme and that the enhanced surveillance linked to the ESM use will only focus on funds being used for COVID-19 health care costs. Furthermore, the Commission added that use by countries will not involve ad hoc on-site missions from the Commission and that surveillance linked to ESM use ends as soon as the money is spent. (Newswires)

UK GfK Consumer Confidence (Apr)-33 (Prev. -34). (Newswires)

FX

The DXY was subdued below the 100.00 level after Fed Fund Rate futures recently began to price in negative rates in the US by year-end and ahead of the looming NFP data. The greenback’s major counterparts benefitted with EUR/USD around the 1.0850 level where there is a large option expiry of EUR 1.9bln set to roll off for today’s New York cut, and it was also reported that the EU Commission is to make it less stringent for using ESM funds in which it will not require a macro-adjustment programme, while GBP/USD extended on its gains and briefly tested the 1.2400 level to the upside despite the BoE forecasting a near-30% economic contraction in H1. Elsewhere, JPY-crosses were underpinned by the heightened risk appetite and antipodeans were spurred due to their high-beta statuses, with AUD/USD also helped by a firmer PBoC reference rate setting and after the RBA Statement on Monetary Policy which stated the RBA is prepared to scale up bond purchases again but noted market functioning has improved and the central bank bond purchases and market operations have been scaled back accordingly.

RBA Statement on Monetary Policy stated it will maintain efforts to keep funding costs low and credit available to households and businesses, while it will not raise the cash rate target until progress is being made towards full employment and is confident inflation will be sustainably within 2%-3% target range. Furthermore, it noted that package of measures has been working broadly as expected so far and is prepared to scale up bond purchases again if necessary to achieve yield target but also stated that market functioning has improved and central bank bond purchases and market operations have been scaled back accordingly. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded mostly positive amid the broad positive risk tone and easing of US-China tensions which provided a lift for copper prices overnight and spurred outperformance in Shanghai commodity prices. Elsewhere, oil prices were higher in which WTI crude futures eventually climbed back above the USD 24/bbl level but with advances limited after the prior day’s fluctuations amid ongoing demand concerns, while gold prices consolidated ahead of the upcoming US jobs data and with the precious metal taking a breather following its recent surge to back above USD 1700/oz as Fed Fund Rate futures priced in negative rates by year-end. 

CME raised natgas Henry Hub futures maintenance margins by 11.1% to USD 2000/contract from 1800/contract. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Senate failed to override the Trump veto of the resolution curtailing his Iran war-making ability. (Newswires)

US

The TPLEX was heavily bid on Thursday, reversing all of the losses incurred after Wednesday’s bazooka refunding announcement. The short-end was particularly sought, where Fed Funds futures began pricing US negative rates in December out. By settlement, 2s -5bps at 0.13%, 5s -8bps at 0.30%, 10s 9bps at 0.63%, 30s -10bps at 1.31%. The grind lower in yields got going as the US session got underway, having risen in APAC and early European trade. There was no new/immediate catalyst for the strength, although desks note the likelihood of participants seizing the rate back-up from Wednesday in anticipation that the Fed would not let the UST curve continue to steepen. Tomorrow’s weekly Fed purchases schedule will be key for gauging the Fed’s tolerance for curve steepening, where it has up to now been tapering its weekly purchases, albeit at a declining rate each week; Morgan Stanley’s analysts believe the two most likely scenarios are either a lowering to USD 30bln per week, or to be maintained at USD 40bln per week, which if the former, the bank expects a steepening of the curve amid the supply/demand dynamic becoming “unfavourable”, while the latter would see little reaction. The TPLEX also continued to rally in the face of record corporate issuance – IFR noted this week marked the third largest for supply ever – where over ten IG issuers came to the dollar market today, including CVX, which is still to announce the size and pricing of its announced seven-parter. US T-note futures (M0) settled 24 ticks higher at 139-09+.

Fed's total balance sheet size rose to USD 6.77tln from USD 6.70tln W/W and Treasury holdings increased to USD 4.02tln from USD 3.97tln W/W, while central bank liquidity swaps rose to USD 444.90bln from USD 438.95bln W/W. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (voter, hawk) said there could be robust growth in H2 if the US economy reopens in June and that banks should not issue large dividends at the moment, while he sees brutally painful Q2 and noted that factories could bounce back but damage to travel and hospitality could be long. Fed's Harker also stated that negative interest rates would not have an effect on the economy in this crisis and evidence on effectiveness of negative rates globally is mixed, while he suggested he has a high hurdle for it. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (non-voter, hawk) said the US is probably "right at" the trough of the economic downturn and the economy went sharply lower but will gradually go up. Furthermore, Barkin added that negative rates have been tried in other places and there is nothing to make him think they are "worth a try" in the US. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia-Pac stocks are buoyed on renewed US-China dialogue and as FFR futures price in negative US rates by year-end
content:
Asia equity markets are higher across the board and US equity futures extend on their gains overnight with the Emini S&P and Mini Dow futures breaching the 2900 and 24000 milestones respectively as global sentiment is underpinned amid optimism after the recent China trade figures and dialogue between US and China trade negotiators, with sentiment further supported after Fed Fund Rate futures began to price in negative rates for the US from December. ASX 200 (+0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.2%) are positive as they take impetus from their Wall St peers and with risk appetite spurred by loosening of coronavirus-related restrictions after Australia’s cabinet agreed to relax some of its social distancing measures in a 3-step phase and with Japan touting the early lifting of the state of emergency in some regions, while Japan is also said to mull additional measures including proposal to subsidize rents for small businesses for up to 6 months. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) join in on the upbeat tone amid the easing of trade tensions following a conference call between USTR Lighthizer, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and China Vice Premier Liu He in which the sides agreed to work together to create a beneficial environment for carrying out the trade deal and to strengthen cooperation on the macro economy, as well as public health.

In FX markets, the DXY is subdued below the 100.00 level after Fed Fund Rate futures recently began to price in negative rates in the US by year-end and following another week of larger than expected jobless claims that preceded the looming NFP data which some expect to show a drop of 22mln jobs. The greenback’s major counterparts have benefitted with EUR/USD around the 1.0850 level where there is a large option expiry of EUR 1.9bln set to roll off for today’s New York cut, and it was also reported that the EU Commission is to make it less stringent for using ESM funds in which it will not require a macro-adjustment programme, while GBP/USD extends on its gains and briefly tested the 1.2400 level to the upside despite the UK bank holiday and recent BoE forecast for a near-30% economic contraction in H1. Elsewhere, JPY-crosses are underpinned by the heightened risk appetite and antipodean benefit due to their high-beta statuses, with AUD/USD also helped by a firmer PBoC reference rate setting and after the RBA Statement on Monetary Policy which stated the RBA is prepared to scale up bond purchases again if necessary to achieve yield target but noted market functioning has improved and the central bank bond purchases and market operations have been scaled back accordingly.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher as they track upside in T-notes as US yields declined amid the pricing of future negative rates, but with price action in JGBs relatively tepid as participants look ahead to the 10yr inflation indexed bond auction.

PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE STOCK NEWS: OCBC eanings decline and Singapore Airlines guides material loss for Q4
content:
TAIWAN

Winbond Electronics (2344 TT) - Co. April rev. rose 11.4% Y/Y to TWD 4.35bln. (Newswires)

 

SINGAPORE

OCBC (OCBC SP) - Co. Q1 net SGD 698mln vs. Prev. SGD 1.2bln Y/Y, NII SGD 1.6bln vs. Prev. SGD 1.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Singapore Airlines (SIA SP) - Co. guides material loss for Q4 and expects small oper. profit but a net loss for FY20, while it has conducted combined capacity reductions of 96% with SilkAir until end of June. (Newswires)

Singapore Post (SPOST SP) - Co. Q4 net SGD 7.2mln vs. Prev. loss SGD 75.1mln Y/Y. (Newswires)
